'''Jonathan D. Gosier''' is an American designer, software developer, philanthropist, investor, and entrepreneur working in areas of data science, human rights, and global development. He is the founder or co-founder of several organizations and initiatives including AfriLabs, [[Appfrica]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2010/04/16/smallbusiness/appfrica/|title=Building tech companies in the land of dialup (CNN) | first=Malika | last=Zouhali-Worrall|date=2010-04-16}}</ref> [[Abayima]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fastcoexist.com/1681223/this-app-lets-activists-pass-around-information-when-the-government-is-watching|title=This App Lets Activists Pass Around Information When The Government Is Watching (FastCompany) | first=Ariel | last=Schwartz|date=2013-01-17}}</ref> [[Hive Colab]], and [[MetaLayer]]. Appfrica is a firm in [[Kampala]], [[Uganda]] that researches and invests in Africa's technology ecosystem.
He has held Executive leadership roles at others including [[Ushahidi]] and QuestionBox.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcworld.com/businesscenter/article/168056/searching_where_google_canand8217t.html/|title=Searching Where Google Can't (PCWorld)}}</ref> He has been described as an ''"African technology guru"'' despite his being [[African-American]].
==Career== In 2009 Gosier spoke at [[TED (Conference)|TEDGlobal]] in [[Oxford]] about his company [[Appfrica]] and one of their projects that connected rural African villages with the Internet. The service, in collaboration with the nonprofit OpenMind, was called [[QuestionBox]], and allowed people with no access to the Internet to ask questions and get timely, vetted answers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/pda/2009/jul/22/mobilephones-searchengines/|title=TEDGlobal: Mobile phone search service for Uganda (Guardian) | location=London | work=The Guardian|first=Kevin|last=Anderson|date=2009-07-22}}</ref> From 2008 to 2010, his blog [[Appfrica]] was a widely-read blog about the emerging African technology sector and became one of the most trafficked blogs on the continent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.netsquared.org/blog/alexsteed/jonathan-gosier-appfrica-talks-front-lines-tech-social-entrepreneurship-east-africa|title=On the front lines of social entrepreneurship}}</ref> Jon is often cited as being one of few prominent 'blacks in technology' along with other prominent African-American technologists like [[Angela Benton]], Wayne Sutton, and [[Baratunde Thurston]].
Gosier's infographic work has been referenced by the British newspaper ''The Guardian'',<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/pda/2009/dec/17/digital-media-mobilephone-usage-africa-leapfroging-ushahidi-swift-river|title=In mobile phone journalism, Africa is ahead of the west | location=London | work=The Guardian|first=Mercedes|last=Bunz|date=2009-12-17}}</ref> FastCompany,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/1645485/kayak-co-founder-starting-initative-to-blanket-africa-in-free-wireless-internet|title=Kayak.com Cofounder Paul English Plans to Blanket Africa in Free Wireless Internet }}</ref> and ''Freakonomics''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://freakonomics.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/11/17/africa-connected/|title=Africa Connected (Freakonomics) | work=The New York Times}}</ref>
==Apps 4 Africa== [[Apps4Africa]] is a competitive funding program for African technologists and innovators whose sponsors include the [[U.S. Department of State]] and [[The World Bank]]. The goal of Apps4Africa is to promote 'African solutions to African problems' by rewarding African technologists seeking ti impact society with their inventions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.state.gov/index.php/site/entry/apps_africa/|title=blogs.state.gov: Apps4Africa}}</ref> The competition asks civil society and citizens throughout the continent to submit local community challenges on issues like transparency and better governance, health, education and more. The project was part of the Obama administration's 21st Century Statecraft initiative. In 2010, United States Secretary of State [[Hillary Rodham Clinton|Hillary Clinton]] congratulated the winners of the first Apps4Africa competition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S1KRd4kFQZc/|title=Secretary Clinton Congratulates Winners of First Apps4Africa Competition}}</ref> In 2012 [[Hillary Rodham Clinton|Hillary Clinton]] kicked of the third Apps4Africa competition with another encouraging message.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2010/10/149048.htm|title=Secretary Clinton Congratulates Winners of First Apps4Africa Competition}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DrYpHUETYGM|title=Hillary Clinton launches the 3rd Annual Apps4Africa competition}}</ref>
==Abayima and Open SIM Kit== In 2012 Jon founded [[Abayima]], a non-profit organization that provides technology solutions for protecting human rights and free speech around the globe. Abayima was inspired by the plight of activists in countries like Uganda, Syria, and Egypt when authorities severed (or monitored) citizen access to the internet or mobile communication. Abayima provides solutions like [http://opensimkit.com Open SIM Kit] which allow citizens and journalists to communicate in spite of such measures during times of crisis. Abayima was a winner of a $150,000 grant in the 2012 Knight News Challenge.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.niemanlab.org/2013/01/a-new-class-of-knight-news-challenge-winners-focuses-on-mobile-in-the-developing-world/|title=A new class of Knight News Challenge winners focuses on mobile in the developing world}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.knightfoundation.org/grants/20123668/|title=Knight Foundation | Abayima}}</ref>
==MetaLayer== Along with longterm business partner Matthew Griffiths, Gosier co-founded [http://www.metalayer.com/ MetaLayer] in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=About metaLayer Inc.|url=http://www.metalayer.com/about.html}}</ref> MetaLayer is a "drag and drop data science" startup that allows non-technical users to perform data-driven research like trend spotting in [[big data]] sets, predictive analytics, and visualization.<ref>{{cite news|title=Meet metaLayer: DreamIt Venturesâ€™ "drag and drop data science" startup|url=http://thenextweb.com/apps/2011/11/02/meet-metalayer-dreamit-ventures-drag-and-drop-data-science-startup/}}</ref>
MetaLayer has been the recipient of a number of honors. The company won the '''Audience Choice Award''' competing against other data startups at the Strata conference,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.metalayer.com/post/18541641659/metalayer-wins-the-startup-showcase-at-strata|title=MetaLayer Wins the Startup Showcase at Strata!}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blip.tv/file/6034541|title=Strata 2012: Democratizing Data Platforms}}</ref> was named the "Next Big Thing in Journalism" by the Paley Center,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cjr.org/the_kicker/paley_center_presents_the_next.php|title=The Next Big Thing in Digital News Innovation}}</ref> one of the 5 Most Promising Startups from DreamIt Ventures,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thenextweb.com/apps/2011/12/08/the-5-most-promising-startups-from-phillys-dreamit-ventures/|newspaper=The Next Web|date=Dec 8, 2011}}</ref> and was showcased at [[TED (Conference)|TED 2012]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Visualizing the full spectrum of TED2012|url=http://blog.ted.com/2012/02/29/visualizing-the-full-spectrum-of-ted2012-a-ted-fellow-maps-the-worlds-reaction/|publisher=TED.com}}</ref>
==Ushahidi and SwiftRiver== In December 2009, Gosier joined [[Ushahidi]] as the Director of SwiftRiver which used [[Big data]], the [[real-time web]] and the [[Semantic Web]] to help validate crowd-sourced reports during times of crisis. In 2011 Jon's work with Ushahidi on SwiftRiver was awarded a Knight News Challenge grant of $250,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.knightdigitalmediacenter.org/news_blog/comments/20110624_data_journalism_a_focal_point_for_latest_knight_news_challenge/|title=Data Journalism a focal point for latest Knight News Challenge}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.knightfoundation.org/grants/20110157/|title=Knight Foundation | SwiftRiver}}</ref>
In March 2010 [[Robert Scoble]] interviewed Ushahidi's Director of Crisis Mapping Patrick Meier about Ushahidi and the mission driving the SwiftRiver project.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sPbwqk97GiY/|title=Robert Scoble interviews Ushahidi Director of Crisis Mapping, Patrick Meier}}</ref> The [[2010 Haiti earthquakes|Haiti Earthquakes]] and Ushahidi's involvement were described by Gosier as being hugely transformative for SwiftRiver, highlighting inefficiencies of disaster response technology.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.casefoundation.org/blog/crowdsourcing-effectively-crisis-qa-jon-gossier-swift-river/|title=Interview with Jon Gosier by the Case Foundation}}</ref>
==Music and Film Career== Early in his career, prior to entering the technology space, Gosier was a producer and [[audio engineer]] at Doppler Studios and Patchwerk Studios in [[Atlanta, Georgia]]. He worked with a number of pop music artists including [[Andre Benjamin]], [[Bryan-Michael Cox]], [[Kanye West]], [[The Pussycat Dolls]], [[Gwen Stefani]], [[Britney Spears]], [[Polow Da Don]], [[Timbaland]], [[Ciara]] and [[The Neptunes]]. Later he was among the first staff members of [[Tyler Perry]] Studios.
